questions.prompt: In BG 18.1, what does Arjuna ask at the beginning of the final chapter?
choices: To clearly explain sannyasa (renunciation) and tyaga (relinquishment)
questions.feedback: Arjuna seeks final clarity on the path of renunciation versus action.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.2, what is the definition of renunciation given?
choices: Relinquishing the desire for fruits; not the action itself
questions.feedback: True renunciation is freedom from selfish motive, not cessation of action.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.3, what do some wise men teach?
choices: All action is tainted by desire; one should abandon it
questions.feedback: Some philosophers advocate complete withdrawal from all activity.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.4-5 teach about the reality of renunciation?
choices: One cannot abandon action; even maintaining body requires action
questions.feedback: Action is inherent in maintaining the body and consciousness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.6, what is the superior path?
choices: Work without desire for fruit; offer it to the Lord
questions.feedback: Selfless work offered to Krishna is superior to renouncing work.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.7, what characterizes true renunciation?
choices: Disliking work but performing duty without attachment; unaffected by results
questions.feedback: The renunciate acts dutifully without selfish attachment.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.8 teach about those who abandon action?
choices: They do not attain perfection; duties must be performed
questions.feedback: Complete inaction cannot lead to spiritual advancement.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.9, what is truly renounced?
choices: The desire for the fruit; not the action itself
questions.feedback: The fruit of action must be relinquished, not the action.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.11, what is stated about karma yoga?
choices: Though imperfect, work performed for the Lord purifies the heart
questions.feedback: Even imperfect work purifies when offered devotionally.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.12 teach about the fruit of renunciation?
choices: The fruits are either peace, pleasure, or destruction based on actions
questions.feedback: The quality of results depends on the mode and nature of action.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.13-14, what are the five factors in action?
choices: Body, doer, senses, effort, and divine providence work together
questions.feedback: Action depends on multiple conditions working together harmoniously.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.15, what determines the fruits of action?
choices: The nature of knowledge, action, and agent; based on modes of nature
questions.feedback: The mode of nature determines the nature and results of action.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.16 teach about the different types of knowledge?
choices: Sattvic knowledge is unified; rajasic is fragmented; tamasic is confused
questions.feedback: The mode of nature qualifies the nature of knowledge.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.17, what defines sattvic action?
choices: Performed without attachment; free from ego; steady and purposeful
questions.feedback: Sattvic action is characterized by equilibrium and selflessness.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.18, what is rajasic action?
choices: Performed with ego, effort, and desire for fruit; causes disturbance
questions.feedback: Rajasic action is driven by personal desire and produces agitation.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.19 teach about tamasic action?
choices: Performed in delusion, without regard for result, consequence, or law
questions.feedback: Tamasic action is reckless and ignores ethical consequences.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.20-22, what are the different types of doers?
choices: Sattvic doer is dedicated; rajasic desires results; tamasic acts in delusion
questions.feedback: The mode of nature determines the nature of the actor.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.26, what is sattvic duty?
choices: One performs duty without attachment, rightly, at proper time
questions.feedback: Sattvic duty is performed with proper discrimination and timing.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.31-32 teach about intelligence?
choices: Sattvic intelligence distinguishes paths; rajasic confuses them; tamasic is deluded
questions.feedback: The mode of nature determines one's capacity for wisdom.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.40-48, what are the duties based on birth?
choices: Four classes exist based on qualities and occupation; each has prescribed duties
questions.feedback: Each person has duties suited to their nature and station.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.49-50, what is the path to perfection?
choices: Perfection comes through devotion to prescribed duty; knowing Krishna in all
questions.feedback: Perfection is achieved by performing one's duty with devotion.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.54 teach about the self-realized person?
choices: Fixed in Krishna consciousness; endowed with supreme peace and bliss
questions.feedback: The realized soul achieves eternal peace through Krishna consciousness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.55, what is the highest path to Krishna?
choices: Through exclusive devotion one can know me, enter my being, and attain the eternal abode
questions.feedback: Pure devotion to Krishna is the ultimate means to liberation.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.62, what is the final instruction to Arjuna?
choices: Seek refuge in Krishna; surrender unto him in all respects
questions.feedback: Complete surrender to Krishna is the highest teaching of the Gita.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.66 conclude about liberation?
choices: I will deliver you from all sin; abandon all else and come to me
questions.feedback: Krishna guarantees complete liberation to those who surrender fully.
